image.altText: Israeli army chief speaking at a lectern in uniform

items.synopsis: While refraining from calling it a ground invasion, the Israel Defence Forces says a number of troops are holding ground in the northern part of the Gaza Strip.

title.children: Israel says troops are holding ground in Gaza in 'next phase' of the war

image.altText: An illustration showing a hand putting a slip of paper into a ballot box, with an Indigenous artwork as a background.

items.synopsis: With the Voice to Parliament resoundingly defeated, many people – including legal experts – have been left wondering whether there is any hope of ever again changing Australia’s 123-year-old constitution.

title.children: A kilo of sausages cost 20 cents last time a referendum passed. Will we ever change the constitution again?

image.altText: The All Blacks perform the Haka before the Rugby World Cup final.

items.synopsis: Play is underway in the Rugby World Cup final, as the All Blacks clash with the Springboks in Paris. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: All Blacks and Springboks meet in Rugby World Cup final

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: MASSIVE HIT FROM EBEN ETZEBETH! Oh my, that's a huge hit as the All Blacks look to spin the ball through hands after a fourth kick out of hands in the opening 90 seconds. Nothing comes from it though and we're going to come back for a knock on. Mbongeni Mbonambi is down getting treatment though and looks in a lot of bother. Shannon Frizell has been pinged for rolling onto the Springbok hooker's leg. YELLOW CARD FOR SHANNON FRIZELL! It's on review for red too, but should stay yellow you'd think. It was a clean out that didn't quite go to plan. Handre Pollard will kick for the posts and the ball just sneaks in. First blood to the Springboks, 3-0. Mbongeni Mbonambi is off, Deon Fourie comes on.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 2' Shannon Frizell yellow card

children.content: MASSIVE HIT FROM EBEN ETZEBETH!
Oh my, that's a huge hit as the All Blacks look to spin the ball through hands after a fourth kick out of hands in the opening 90 seconds.
Nothing comes from it though and we're going to come back for a knock on.
Mbongeni Mbonambi is down getting treatment though and looks in a lot of bother.
(Getty Images)
Shannon Frizell has been pinged for rolling onto the Springbok hooker's leg.
YELLOW CARD FOR SHANNON FRIZELL!
It's on review for red too, but should stay yellow you'd think. It was a clean out that didn't quite go to plan.
Handre Pollard will kick for the posts and the ball just sneaks in.
First blood to the Springboks, 3-0.
Mbongeni Mbonambi is off, Deon Fourie comes on.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand kick us off deep into the Springbok 22, and Damian Willemse hammers it straight out to touch on half way.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 1' We're underway in the Rugby World Cup final

children.content: New Zealand kick us off deep into the Springbok 22, and Damian Willemse hammers it straight out to touch on half way.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wayne Barnes of England is today's referee, the world's most capped official rewarded for another good tournament with the whistle. Barnes, 44, has officiated in 110 Tests since taking charge of Fiji vs Samoa in Suva in June 2006. He is the second Englishman to take charge of a Rugby World Cup final. The last Englishman to do so? Ed Morrison. When did he officiate a final? 1995, the last time New Zealand and South Africa met in the decider. The match will be Barnes's record 27th Rugby World Cup contest in what is his fifth tournament. It's his sixth match in the middle during France 2023 - he has refereed New Zealand twice - in their quarterfinal win over Ireland and their 73-0 thrashing of Uruguay in the pool stages. He has not refereed South Africa in an international since November 12, 2022, when the Boks lost to France 30-26 in Marseille. Barnes sent Pieter-Steph du Toit off after just 12 minutes, before levelling the sides at 14 men each with Antoine Dupont was also shown a red card. Sir Bill Beaumont, World Rugby chairman, praised Barnes for his longevity. "On behalf of World Rugby, I would like to congratulate Wayne Barnes on his deserved appointment as the Rugby World Cup 2023 final referee," Sir Bill said. "Such an appointment is a reflection of Wayne’s calibre, not just at this tournament but over a distinguished career. "It is a result of his devotion to the game, the support of his family and the spirit of collaboration and excellence that exists across our entire match official team." World Rugby High Performance 15s Match Official Manager Joël Jutge said: "Wayne’s ability to read and understand the game is second to none. He also embodies the passion, professionalism and dedication that is at the heart of a superb team of match officials at this Rugby World Cup.". Karl Dickson and Matthew Carley (both England) are the assistant referees, while Tom Foley is the Television Match Official.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who is the referee?

children.content: (Getty Images)
Wayne Barnes of England is today's referee, the world's most capped official rewarded for another good tournament with the whistle.
Barnes, 44, has officiated in 110 Tests since taking charge of Fiji vs Samoa in Suva in June 2006.
He is the second Englishman to take charge of a Rugby World Cup final.
The last Englishman to do so? Ed Morrison.
When did he officiate a final? 1995, the last time New Zealand and South Africa met in the decider.
The match will be Barnes's record 27th Rugby World Cup contest in what is his fifth tournament.
It's his sixth match in the middle during France 2023 - he has refereed New Zealand twice - in their quarterfinal win over Ireland and their 73-0 thrashing of Uruguay in the pool stages.
(Getty Images)
He has not refereed South Africa in an international since November 12, 2022, when the Boks lost to France 30-26 in Marseille.
Barnes sent Pieter-Steph du Toit off after just 12 minutes, before levelling the sides at 14 men each with Antoine Dupont was also shown a red card.
Sir Bill Beaumont, World Rugby chairman, praised Barnes for his longevity.
"On behalf of World Rugby, I would like to congratulate Wayne Barnes on his deserved appointment as the Rugby World Cup 2023 final referee," Sir Bill said.
"Such an appointment is a reflection of Wayne’s calibre, not just at this tournament but over a distinguished career.
"It is a result of his devotion to the game, the support of his family and the spirit of collaboration and excellence that exists across our entire match official team."

World Rugby High Performance 15s Match Official Manager Joël Jutge said: "Wayne’s ability to read and understand the game is second to none. He also embodies the passion, professionalism and dedication that is at the heart of a superb team of match officials at this Rugby World Cup.".
Karl Dickson and Matthew Carley (both England) are the assistant referees, while Tom Foley is the Television Match Official.

image.altText: Madonna's Rebel Heart tour

title.children: Hubble telescope captures image of 'galactic dance'
